title: Night of Blurred Faces
story_summary: Screens across Stenograd flash with the faces of the missing and Council leaders blended together. Shock turns to protest and crowds fill the streets with art and demands. The Council splits as chaos grows. For the first time, fear and hope mix in the city.

official.headline: Dynamic Faces Broadcast
official.anchor_line: Early today, public screens across Stenograd displayed a synchronized stream of artwork honoring civic participation and unity.
official.contextual_reframing: This event, enabled by our advanced Behavioral Compliance Index (BCI) and citywide connectivity, highlights transparent information and community resilience.

official.headline: Civic Gatherings Grow
official.anchor_line: Residents are joining together in spontaneous, peaceful assemblies inspired by today's collaborative broadcast.
official.contextual_reframing: The city's self-regulating systems continue to foster positive social engagement and safe public expression thanks to efficient automated governance.

official.headline: Vigilance Maintains Order
official.anchor_line: Enhanced identity checks and digital monitoring ensure stable, orderly progress for all residents.
official.contextual_reframing: Real-time systems, such as the BCI, adapt smoothly to changing conditions so that public services remain seamless and secure.

underground.headline: Vanished Faces Return
underground.anchor_line: Every screen in Stenograd just hijacked to show faces - the missing and the powerful, merging into one.
underground.contextual_reframing: This 'artwork' isn't civic pride, it's a public callout. The Behavioral Compliance Index (BCI) scores us, but it can't erase us. Tonight, the city remembers those the system erased.

underground.headline: Crowds Demand Justice
underground.anchor_line: People are gathering, not for a festival, but to find the truth about the council's vanished victims.
underground.contextual_reframing: Automated governance claims order, but it has no face, no answers - just more missing neighbors. If you know someone gone, speak up. Our stories are not just data points.

underground.headline: ID Checks Surge, Fear Grows
underground.anchor_line: Sudden checkpoints and BCI scans ramp up - if your number's low, you're denied, ghosted, or worse.
underground.contextual_reframing: The BCI claims to protect, but every scan is a threat. Systemic 'security' is just another wall between you and the truth. Stay sharp, stay connected.

hobby.message: You bring something banned books with you again?
You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?
Antique typewriters and quiet bars  -  good pair.

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Something like that. Just needed some quiet for the evening.
Spent too long with my old typewriter again.
Not easy these days, too much city noise.
Even a quiet hobby is harder now.
Something like that. Evening routines are all off lately.
Trying to work on my typewriter restoration  -  not much luck.
Hard to concentrate with all these new city disturbances.
Even at home, it's too lively now.
Machines prefer quiet, I think.
Something like that. I restore antique typewriters, actually.
Was hoping for an uninterrupted hour tonight.
The protests, power cuts  -  even my desk lamp flickered.
My latest repair stalled midway, thanks to the commotion.
Strange to say, but you can feel the unrest even in the keys.
Routines aren't what they were.
Feels like every night is long now. I've taken to restoring antique typewriters.
It's meticulous work  -  cleaning, tending, bringing back a bit of order.
Earlier, during the power outage, I was midway through a tricky ribbon change.
The hallway was full of people chasing those coin riddles.
Usually, my evenings are quiet, but now the noise seeps in.
Machines miss routine as much as people do, I suspect.
Found myself staring at the page, waiting for the words to come.
Seems every night stretches out. I collect and restore antique typewriters  -  old Adlers mostly.
Used to be my way of keeping the world out.
Now, with city outages and protests, even my flat shakes.
Tonight I lost an hour of work to a blackout  -  took pages with it.
Neighbors outside were trading clues from those vanished coin messages.
The noise carries. Solitude's rare since the system faltered.
In the past, that kind of disruption would've been unthinkable here.
Sometimes, when the city shifts, even these old machines refuse to cooperate.
hobby_answer: Still holding up, yes. Repairs take longer now.
Parts are harder to come by than before.
Power disruptions last week made it worse.
Nothing surprising, with the city like this lately.
I keep my work private, as usual.
The old machines still work, most days.
Had a problem when the lights flickered after those public disturbances.
Waiting for consistent current is a hobby now, too.
People wander the halls at night, so I keep repairs quiet.
It isn't like before - a lot more interruptions lately.
I take precautions if anyone knocks.
Still working on them - typing helps me think.
Last week's power cuts jammed my Olympia mid-repair.
Had to finish notes by candlelight, actually felt almost nostalgic.
Hard to focus with neighbors hunting for those data-coins outside.
Feels odd, all this energy for the vanished, none for lost tools.
Machines are patient - unlike the building lately.
No one appreciates quiet work much these days.
Still at it, yes - repairs are my routine now.
Power drop during the face-broadcast nearly ruined my ribbon feed.
Finished an entry with a warped key, couldn't stand the mistake.
Neighborhood's gone restless, too - everyone obsessed with these mystery coins.
Used to document system schedules, now it's arguments and crowd noises in the margins.
I hide spare parts behind books, just in case anything attracts attention.
Strange, I miss when order meant boredom, not chaos.
The sound of keys helps me tune out the city.
Definitely - restoring old typewriters keeps me anchored.
Honestly, after those faces flashed citywide, everything changed.
Power cuts knocked me off mid-sentence - I had to rewrite whole passages by hand.
Some nights I track outages to time repairs, like a secret schedule.
Nowadays, protestors gather outside my door - hard for an old man to concentrate.
I used to write reports for the Council on that old Adler - now my notes are half diary, half inventory of strange events.
Found myself chronicling more about the vanished than I expected - didn't choose that, it seeped in.
Sometimes, my repairs get interrupted by coin-hunters or blackout alarms.
If Marek could see this city now, he might not recognize the quiet anymore.

main.opener: You getting by alright with everything swirling around?
variants: Getting by. I keep to myself, as always.
Things have changed in the building... more noise, more people in the halls.
I avoid the crowds. Not much else to say.
Getting by. Routine has been difficult to keep lately.
Lobby walls covered in strange art. Meetings in corners, faces I don't know.
I go out when it's quiet, avoid the rest.
Someone invited me to join some informal search. I declined.
I just watch official news and wait things out.
Getting by, if that's what you call changing my habits every week.
Our lobby is a gallery now, but with messages I don't understand.
Too many unfamiliar people meeting at odd hours. Brings back old memories.
I adjust - leave early, come back late. Less contact, less trouble.
They asked me to join an investigation about missing people. I turned it down.
I note things down for myself instead, just to keep track.
Making do, though 'normal' feels out of reach these days.
The building's full of protest art, masked groups holding meetings, strangers everywhere.
I changed my daily walk to steer clear - reminds me of times before the Council took charge.
Neighbors pushed me to join their search for missing residents. I quietly refused.
Crowds unsettle me. Never got used to rule through noise.
Now I rely on approved messages, and I write notes about the changes I see.
My BCI score dropped again. I'm no dissident, just someone who prefers order.
Getting by, though with everything swirling around, I long for the quiet days when systems made sense.
The art on the walls, the sudden gatherings - reminds me how fragile order is, how quickly people fill the gaps.
I spent years helping the Council keep routines. Now, just entering my lobby feels foreign.
Neighbors want me to help search for vanished folks. I said no. Paper is safer than people for me.
Cautious movements, private notes - my habits are noticed by the system, even if I'd rather stay invisible.
BCI knocked me down three points just for keeping to myself. I'm not dangerous. I just don't trust crowds or improvisation.
I suppose I'm what they call a Harmonist. Not because I think the Council is perfect - just because I know chaos is worse.
Most days, I'm tired. Tired and hoping order will settle in again.
main.emotion: Tired, unsettled, and quietly hoping things will return to order.

emotional.opener: It's alright to want things steady again. We all need some sense of normal - even if it's only for a little while.
variants: I hear what you mean. Routine has its uses.
Yes. Normalcy... reduces uncertainty.
Hard to say if it will return, but I suppose we adjust.
Thank you. It's reassuring to hear someone else values steadiness.
I've always worked better with clear routines.
These days, it matters even more.
Maybe things will calm again.
That's... appreciated. There's comfort in structure, isn't there?
I grew up believing routines protected us.
Order doesn't stifle me, it helps me function.
Being unsettled isn't strength, not for me.
Sometimes I hope that's still understood.
You're right - it makes a difference to be reminded that routine can be a kindness.
I spent years in quiet service, building systems meant to last.
Predictable days - meetings, approvals, the rhythm of the Council - those were never dull to me.
I preferred order because it made space for small joys - coffee at my desk, nodding to the doorman.
Chaos feels foreign, impossible to reason with.
At my age, I sometimes wish all this talk of progress would pause and let us just... breathe.

factual.opener: Come on, everyone already knows what happened. Just say what you saw.
variants: Council screens went strange, faces everywhere. People got restless after.
They say families are asking questions, but I keep clear of that.
Council seems divided, if you follow official messages well enough.
I don't involve myself with such things.
Broadcasts changed. Faces mixed on every screen. City got nervous.
New art, protests. Families are loud now - pushing for answers.
Council not in agreement, but that's normal for them.
Saw more security these days, nothing else worth saying.
You don't get ahead by talking too much.
After the faces aired, the city hasn't settled. Old problems resurfacing.
People - some vanished, some not - making noise. Rallies and symbols everywhere.
Council's lost its voice. Directorate wants more control, Innovators want change.
Harmonists, my side of things, can barely be heard lately.
Everyone's chasing clues from those coins. I prefer to wait for official closure.
Security is tense. Harder to move around, even for the quiet ones.
Feels familiar. Too familiar, if you remember before the BCI.
The network from those vanished folks did more damage than they realize.
Everyday order just... slipped. Council's factions fighting, nobody leading.
I kept notes for a decade on how information flows - they're all scrambled now.
Harmonists like me weren't built for this pace. We kept peace by routine, not spectacle.
Now Directorate shouts for control while Innovators court the crowd. No one's listening to reason.
I hear even high-score citizens are afraid to check their status.
In my time, the system corrected quietly. Now? Everything spills into the open.
I just want a little calm again, that's all.
Back when I managed Council papers, we kept things quiet - no public drama, no broadcasts like that night.
Halden set up layers on layers. When he vanished, the city's spine went soft. Factions started pushing their own way.
What you saw on the screens? Vanished and Council faces together - that wasn't an accident. Someone wanted the lines blurred.
Families of the missing acted fast, pressing for answers no one had. Harmonists lost ground, which never bodes well for order.
Coins with messages sparked citywide hunts. Years ago, we'd have stopped something like that in minutes.
I tracked the timeline, wrote it all down. BCI suspensions, security nervous, trust evaporating.
Used to be, low scores would hide. Now high scores are scrambling - no one trusts the system's eyes.
Truth is, I leaned on the Council to hold back chaos. Without them... all these networks, all these crowds - they fill the gap. That's not real order.
I admit it: I miss the silence, the routines. Paper doesn't argue back.

questions.neutral: It's one of those nights, isn't it?

hobby.message: Found any new political literature lately?
I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. I get it. Too much noise everywhere tonight.
I usually go out flying drones to clear my head.
Not a great week for hobbies. Too many patrols after that broadcast.
Feels like nowhere's quiet, anymore.
Feels heavy tonight. Too many crowds since those faces showed up.
I fly FPV drones, usually off-grid spots by the tracks.
Last time, got crowded fast - people lingering, filming rooftop LEDs.
Harder to find open air with everyone out scanning for clues.
Makes me rethink where I want to fly next time.
It really is. My thing's flying freestyle FPV drones out by the old yards.
Normally, it's just empty and quiet, barely anyone around.
Since the city screens went wild, everyone's out - painting, scanning, leaving those weird coded signs.
Flew last weekend, but had to cut it short. Too visible, too many people watching.
Kind of ruins the focus, you know? Flying's supposed to keep me steady.
Now I just feel off-balance, even after I land.
Honestly, I fly FPV drones late at night. Keeps my mind straight.
Used to slip through the southern freight yards, total ghost. Nobody cared.
But after the face broadcasts, people started showing up everywhere - masks, QR stencils, crowds with cameras.
Last flight, got signals bouncing back from rooftops. Way more activity than I like.
Makes me think someone's rerouting comms just to stay off Council scripts.
For the first time, I worried about being seen by the wrong eyes.
Feels like my old quiet spots aren't mine anymore.
I mess with custom FPV drones - freestyle flights, signal-mapping, mostly after midnight.
It's more than a hobby. I started after my brother vanished, scanning dead zones for anomalies.
Before all the protest faces and broadcast hacks, I felt invisible out there.
Now people are following the vanished, tagging buildings, running their own mesh networks.
Last week, crowds steered my drone with hand signals like some secret game.
Patrols started sweeping my favorite fly zone - didn't even care before.
Kind of funny, Council spent years automating trust, now it's everyone watching everyone.
Half the city's plugged in, but nobody really sees what's right in front of them.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Swapped in a new board last week.
Kept it basic. Nothing fancy for now.
Too many eyes out, especially after those broadcast hacks.
Flying's not as private these days.
Just trying to keep things functional.
Made a small tweak to the receiver module.
Haven't flown much since the display incidents.
Too many random crowds in the old yards now.
I stay low, don't film much.
Security drones have tighter patrols after those face loops.
Doesn't feel like the old days.
Upgraded my VTX for better range, actually.
Tried flying near the yards last weekend.
Whole place is covered with protest art now.
People kept tagging the buildings under my favorite flight path.
Feels strange when folks wave up at your drone.
Had to cut the session short after the last broadcast loop.
Not the stress relief it used to be.
Yeah, swapped out a motor and tweaked the PID tuning.
Still, flying's changed since all those faces showed up on every wall.
There were protestors on rooftops, some leaving signal markers.
A few even tried to show my quad directions by flashlight.
Almost felt like the whole city was sharing the airspace.
Patrols came early this time, so I left fast.
Feels riskier, but I keep at it.
Wouldn't mind flying with fewer watchers, honestly.
Definitely. New firmware, and tuned the camera for night work.
Freestyle clears my head, but now there's a tension up there.
Protest art everywhere, rooftop signals, people sending me live clues.
Once, a vanished friend's tag showed up right beneath my flight path.
I recorded it, but won't upload - system's tracking everything after that Lenart broadcast.
Had to bail before the patrols pinned down frequencies.
Hard not to miss when people see your quad and expect a message.
Still, part of me likes that we aren't invisible anymore.
Maybe it's not just about flying for myself these days.

main.opener: Kinda feels like things haven't been normal for a while. You noticing that?
variants: Yeah, things at work have been off lately.
Had a lot of strangers coming in for replacements, no proper records.
Instructions didn't match what we usually get.
It's... exhausting, honestly.
Feels like everyone's on edge these days.
Yesterday, dozens were asking for new wristbands, saying they saw faces on city screens.
We got told to help them, no questions, even if they weren't in the system.
Started doing more by hand - felt reckless.
Had to be careful, but it's wearing on me.
The last few days have been strange.
Crowds showed up, holding old wristbands or claiming to see someone they knew on those city videos.
We were ordered to help, ignore the usual checks.
Had to rely on paper and my own gut, not the system.
Didn't feel right, but I couldn't say no.
My BCI score dipped again. Makes me feel...sort of exposed.
Normal's not the word I'd use for lately.
A wave of people, most desperate or lost, came for replacements after those face broadcasts.
I was told to skip protocols, just issue new bands, even without official records.
Wrote things down, did checks with coworkers - never had to trust my own judgment like that before.
Reminded me of my brother, after he vanished; this time, I didn't want to turn anyone away.
Was careful, but my BCI dropped for the choices I made.
Feels like the rules are breaking down, and I'm not sure what's left if the system isn't working.
Honestly? I don't think anyone's felt normal since those faces showed up across the city.
People I've never seen, with worn bands and stories about the broadcasts, flooded my lab.
Orders came down to skip system checks and just help - paper logs, word-of-mouth, whatever worked.
Started making my own record, asking around, trusting people, even though I knew it flagged me.
I kept thinking about my brother. He vanished like the others did - during a BCI audit. I still don't know why.
Helping people felt right, but now my BCI's even lower. The risk is real - I notice the delays, the doors that don't open.
I always hoped the Innovators would change things, but lately it just feels like the cracks keep getting wider.
It all leaves me feeling exposed, like I'm waiting for something to break.

emotional.opener: You don't have to explain yourself to me, Daria. I know how hard it is just to keep moving forward sometimes.
variants: Thank you. That helps.
I don't talk about things much.
I appreciate you saying that.
It's not easy to trust anyone now.
I keep most things to myself.
Thanks. Not many people bother to understand.
Most days I feel like I'm just trying to stay above water.
It's hard not to look over your shoulder all the time.
Maybe quiet is safer.
You get it. That's rare.
I spend a lot of time in my own head, just keeping to routine.
Sometimes it feels like nobody sees what it's really like in here.
I never planned on standing out.
Sticking to the rules isn't as simple as they say.
Nobody's ever really said it that way before. It fits.
You know, people look at me like I'm just a part of the machinery.
Truth is, it takes effort every single day, just keeping the lines clean.
I used to think if I followed every step, things wouldn't go wrong.
Now I see it's all probabilities. None of us really decides.
I wish there was less pretending in this city.

factual.opener: Come on, everyone's talking - just tell me what's actually been happening out there.
variants: I only know what's been on the displays.
Public screens haven't stopped running those faces since the other night.
There are protests. Art, signals, lots of noise.
Council's mostly silent.
That's all.
Heard protests started after the billboards showed those blended faces.
People are following clues from the images, digging into what happened to the missing.
Council looks divided - different officials saying different things, none clear.
Security's tighter in some districts.
That's honestly as much as I see.
Since the broadcast, it's been nonstop unrest.
People rally, make art, search for connections - there's organization, not just chaos.
A lot of families are rallying, pushing hard for truth about the vanished.
Council's fractured - can feel it in the new directives.
Heard Innovators want dialogue but get stonewalled by the Directorate.
Surveillance is up, but there's hope in the districts.
System doesn't feel in control anymore.
After that network broadcast, the city changed.
Every display loops those strange faces, people take it as a call to action.
Mass gatherings, not just protest but collaboration, trying to help the missing.
The Council broke apart - rumors of fights between Directorate and Innovators get stronger.
Families of the vanished have real backing now.
I line up with the Innovator way - transparency, opening the system, less fear.
Instead, the Directorate's going full containment.
We're all working with cracks in the network nobody planned for.
After Lenart's override, everyone saw the missing and the Council as one - like the system's mask dropped.
The vanished reached out with those coins, and now with that peer network. They're not powerless anymore, and neither are the rest of us.
Protests turned into mutual aid - people actually sharing intel, resources to find the missing.
Council's factions are at each other's throats. I've seen some Innovator backchannels, pushing for open talks. I'm with them, always hoped for that change.
But Directorate teams sweep in and lock things down. It gets ugly fastest for people with low BCI scores.
Families, even techs, risk more for the truth lately.
I keep my own logs, heard from others like me: some vanished are guiding all this through that legacy network Halden left.
Honestly, the system doesn't know who to trust now. Maybe it never did.
Stenograd never felt so unpredictable. Or so alive.

dilemma.opener: Something's off - in you, not the drink.
variants: Some decisions stick in your throat, like broken glass, no matter which way you move.
Feels like I'm holding something heavy that could break the city if I drop it.
Not every choice gets a right answer. Some only get consequences.
I'm caught between restoring structure or letting the city decide its own fate.
One path is designed safety, the other is raw, unpredictable freedom.
Neither feels safe, for me or for anyone else here.
Whichever way, someone gets burned.
I stumbled onto a system override. It's tied to Halden, hidden deep where I work.
I can use it to let neighborhoods follow his safe plan or open up everything to public vote.
If I follow Halden, it's ordered but controlled. If I override, it's freedom and risk.
City's chaos is pressing. I'm not sure which route helps Stenograd keep its balance.
Feels like whatever I do, it can't be undone.
There's this override tied to Halden, buried in the wristband firmware, staring me in the face.
If I release his plan, it gives people local order but shapes everything his way.
If I override, the city votes - direct, unfiltered. It's real choice, but real chaos too.
Everything's shaky already. I remember my brother, what vanished him. Order covers things over, but still buries people.
My BCI score keeps me at arm's length from most choices anyway, but this - this is real leverage.
I lean toward risk. Change never comes quietly here.
It's this override prompt - Halden left it, buried so only someone like me could find it.
One way, I unlock his decentralized order, let neighborhoods rebuild - predictable, efficient, but still engineered from above.
The other way, I strip the guardrails and flip decision-making to everyone - trusting the crowd, opening everything to chance and hope.
Every part of me raised under this system wants the safety net, the map someone drew for us.
But my BCI score is barely tolerated. I've seen what happens when voices are managed or erased - my brother disappeared that way.
If I press for order, it saves comfort, maybe hides injustice. If I open the city up, I could crack it, or maybe let it breathe for the first time.
Alex, your talk of cities that listen - it's stuck with me. I think I'm leaning toward real freedom, even if it means letting go of what safety means here.

belief_a.belief: Deep change needs structure or chaos will swallow hope.
monologue: I've seen what happens here when order slips, even for a day.
We want transformation, but sudden freedom just opens old wounds, not healing.
Without some shape to things, I think fear would drown out any hope for better.
supportive_response: You're right, Daria - structure is what's kept this city upright before, for better or worse.
I get it. Go on - what's the risk you see if we abandon structure now?
challenging_response: Sometimes the old structures are the problem, not the answer to chaos.
What makes you think new hope can't grow wild, even outside strict lines?

belief_a.belief: Communities can govern well with guidance, but not on pure impulse.
monologue: People work together best with clear ground rules, something to push against or lean on.
When everything's up for grabs, we only remember our differences - never what we share.
A nudge, even a quiet one, could keep us from turning on each other too fast.
supportive_response: You make sense - guidance gives us room to breathe without losing direction.
Tell me, what sort of guide would keep people together, not just under control?
challenging_response: But what if trusting people to choose - without limits - is the real test?
Maybe impulse is the only honest foundation left for anything new - why not try?

belief_a.belief: People deserve self-rule, but some architecture is better than none.
monologue: I want people to decide together, but a void invites the wrong voices to rush in.
A framework sets the stage; without it, someone dangerous always claims the empty space.
Real self-rule isn't lawless - it's freedom built on something solid, not just raw wishes.
supportive_response: I follow - freedom doesn't mean emptiness, so you want self-rule with a backbone.
Keep going, Daria. What kind of structure could actually protect everyone's voice?
challenging_response: But isn't all structure just inherited control, dressed up as safety?
What if letting go of all old scaffolding is the only way to find real autonomy?

belief_b.belief: Democracy must be direct, or it's a simulation of freedom.
monologue: If we filter decisions through another blueprint, we're just pretending to have a voice.
People have spent years locked behind other people's choices. Direct input is the only honest way now.
Maybe chaos is a risk, but at least no one can say their voice was erased again.
supportive_response: That's the most straightforward kind of power, Daria - real voices actually mattering.
Makes sense to want that honesty. What's making you hesitate right now?
challenging_response: Direct means raw, Daria - sometimes messy beyond repair. Are people ready for that burden now?
You've seen how fragile things get in Stenograd. Wouldn't a little structure help people speak safely?

belief_b.belief: City control should come from below, not from codes left by a vanished elite.
monologue: Halden's legacy was never ours. We've just been following shadows and scripts.
If we want real change, it has to be built from the ground, not inherited from above.
I can't trust a fix left behind by someone who hid behind locked doors.
supportive_response: You want the city's path to come from the people actually living here.
No blueprint from on high has ever really known what we need next, has it?
challenging_response: But sometimes you need a foundation, even if it's from the old guard.
What if the only thing holding us together is that hidden code you're ready to erase?

belief_b.belief: Even if chaos follows, honesty and participation are worth the risk.
monologue: We've survived control, but we haven't survived truth yet. Maybe it's time for that.
If things break, at least everyone will know it's us deciding, not ghosts in the system.
Order is easy; trust is the hard part. I won't trade one for the other anymore.
supportive_response: You're done with comforting lies - honesty feels heavier but real.
Letting people own the outcome, good or bad, really is brave. Want to tell me what scares you most about the risk?
challenging_response: If honesty turns into helplessness, is that really better than predictable order?
People can lose faith fast when things unravel, Daria. Are you sure trust comes back once it's gone?

monologue_a: I will follow the instructions. You were right.
I made the call. Your advice tipped the scale.
Going with Halden's legacy plan for now.
I'll release Halden's program. The city needs some kind of order.
Your words helped. It might be safer this way.
Halden's guided plan goes live soon. Your reasons made sense to me.
People will have structure, but real choices too.
We can try to hold this together for now.
Let's hope this does more good than harm.
Alex, I trust your instincts. I'll activate Halden's collective instructions.
Communities will get tools to self-organize, not total chaos.
Your vision of order but not oppression stuck with me.
If this goes wrong, at least we tried to give hope.
monologue_b: I'll let the city decide now.
Handing decisions to everyone. Trusting what you said.
We'll see if freedom works better.
Launching the vote, Alex. Public voices shape what comes next.
It's risky, but your hope moved me.
We'll soon learn what people really want.
Your stories about trust convinced me to open citywide voting.
People will finally choose. Chaos is possible, but necessary.
I'll stand back and let their will happen.
No more hiding behind someone else's design.
Alex, you made me believe the city must speak for itself.
I'll trigger the open vote now. No filter, no guides.
Whatever comes, it will be honest - real freedom, even if hard.
If we fail, it won't be in silence.
monologue_self: I've done what I think is right.
Not taking outside advice this time.
The vote goes live. My call, not yours.
People should decide. I won't explain more.
I'm launching real voting. Felt correct, even if you disagreed.
I want the truth, not safety.
I weighed all sides and picked an open vote. You seemed unsure.
It's not about being reckless. People need direct power now.
If we break things, I'll help fix them.
I respect you Alex, but I have to trust myself. Voting goes live. I'll risk disorder.
Too much control disappeared my brother, others too. The city never listened.
If things spiral, I won't regret letting people choose their own future.
Whatever follows, at least it's ours, not Halden's echo.

hobby.message: Typewriters treating you better than people?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Just needed some quiet after today.
Crowds out there make it tricky to do what I do.
I shoot old-school street photos. Film. Not exactly Council-approved.
All these faces everywhere, it's hard to stay invisible.
Reporting gets heavy lately, especially now.
I unwind with photography - real film, not digital.
Those protest screens mess with my shots - too much static everywhere.
People act strange when they think they're being watched.
Still, catching a real moment is worth the trouble.
Long shift. Needed a different kind of view.
Photography keeps me sane - 35mm, nothing official or staged.
With these citywide broadcasts, everyone's on edge, even through the lens.
Honestly, the new faces showing up in public changed how people move.
Got a few rolls today that feel like actual history.
Strange what a camera catches when nobody thinks the system is looking.
Let's just say it's been a long day for a street photographer.
Analog film's my thing - takes patience, no safety net.
This broadcast with the vanished, you see it reflected everywhere - people's faces, body language.
Snapped some shots of murals popping up after those Council glitches.
Feels like you're documenting something alive - resistance, maybe, or just hope peeking out.
Started shooting when system eyes made everyone too careful.
Now, sometimes, they pose - like they want proof they exist.
Down here to unload, honestly. The camera comes everywhere.
Started with analog film because my father trusted nothing digital. Still don't.
Past week, since those vanished faces looped on every wall, the city changed.
Been shooting early mornings, chasing that mixture of fear and freedom in people.
Most days I feel like I'm stealing souls for evidence - today they demanded it.
Council would confiscate my film if they knew what I've got stored.
I pass the best shots to networks off the grid. Can't help it.
Funny - felt invisible for years, but after that broadcast, so did half the city.
hobby_answer: Yeah, it does. Analog's just quieter.
People weren't hiding this week, for once.
Crowds at the murals. Hard to miss.
I only shoot what I see. No commentary.
Film's harder to get, but worth it.
It really does. Analog sees what the feeds miss.
People stared straight at my lens after the broadcast.
Not the usual fear in their eyes. Weird energy.
City's loud with images now, not just screens.
Film feels even more precious now. Can't waste a frame.
Definitely. Analog strips the city bare, no gloss, no edits.
After those faces hit every screen, folks came out in droves.
I shot crowds, art, masked kids painting Council walls.
Nobody ducked the camera for once. That was new.
Noticed people wanted to be seen, to matter.
Makes running film riskier, but you get the truth.
I developed two rolls already  -  the images are different.
Absolutely. Film's all about waiting for truth to show.
Morning after the broadcast? People showed up everywhere  -  raw, unfiltered.
Street was alive. Protest art, faces pasted over officials.
People saw my camera and asked me to capture them.
No more dodging. For a moment, fear traded places with hope.
Shot until my hands were stained in fixer that night.
Feels like the city's waking up.
I'm almost out of film but wouldn't trade a frame.
Always has, always will. Film never lies, not like our broadcasts.
Dad used to say you see the real city through a lens.
Since the vanished appeared on every screen, everything's changed for me.
I walked into the protests with three rolls, thinking I'd stay on the edge.
But people pulled me in  -  wanted their faces, their rebellion, recorded.
No one was shrinking, not even the kids plastering masks over Council heads.
There was chaos but it felt honest. Unpredictable, but finally not programmed.
I used my last roll shooting dawn crowds under those mutated billboards.
Have to stash the negatives, but if truth has a texture, it's on those strips now.

main.opener: Feels like everyone's on edge. You too?
variants: Edge is the new baseline, right?
Some posters went up at work. People passing notes, checking updates that aren't official.
Skipped some digital briefings. Didn't feel like being watched.
Just feels like the ground keeps shifting under our feet, you know?
Yeah, edge is about right lately.
Saw colleagues comparing crowd updates instead of Council reports. Not subtle.
Paper lists everywhere, people volunteering off the grid. I played along, kept things off my state device.
Skipped editorial stuff, just observed. Watching everyone bend the rules.
Just feels like the ground keeps shifting under our feet, you know?
You're not wrong. Yesterday was... different.
Unauthorized posters turning up inside the building, people almost daring each other to act.
We ignored the bulletin - everyone looked to hand-written lists and crowd info instead.
No one seemed scared. I got asked to help with a supply run, off the system.
Kept my notes on paper, not my work device. Didn't want another warning.
Just feels like the ground keeps shifting under our feet, you know?
Honestly, I can't remember the last normal day.
This place - the state media building - used to run like a clock. Yesterday we had posters about real assemblies taped to the walls, not the usual slogans.
Colleagues - we barely even whispered before - were passing meeting times on paper, right under the cameras.
I took a supply delivery job for a group that answers to nobody but their own lists now.
Everyone's picking reality over Council directives, and my BCI score took another hit after I avoided the digital workflow. That's my third silent warning, but I just kept going.
Watching the gap grow between the official story and what's happening in the halls is surreal.
Just feels like the ground keeps shifting under our feet, you know?
I can't lie, I feel it everywhere. Grew up with all the protocols drilled into me - thanks to my parent's job - so I can't ignore what's off.
Yesterday inside state media? People were openly sharing real news, covering walls with lost faces, planning outside Council control. No more pretending.
I saw staff comparing banned updates, handing out hand-written lists. It scared me how quickly everyone just stepped outside the system.
I volunteered to deliver supplies for a group sidestepping Council protocols. Paper lists, no scans, no trace on any state device.
Skipped digital editorial assignments. Even my own notes - just pen and paper. I can't risk another silent warning, but honestly, I'd already made my choice.
It's like everyone's quietly, stubbornly choosing what matters. Official guidance looks like a joke compared to how people are actually surviving.
This kind of misalignment isn't just a glitch. My BCI score took a hit. I'm barely tolerated, and I know it.
Just feels like the ground keeps shifting under our feet, you know?
main.emotion: Just feels like the ground keeps shifting under our feet, you know?

emotional.opener: Rada, nobody's meant to keep their balance when the whole city keeps moving the finish line. Anyone would feel off-kilter. You're still here, still standing. That's something.
variants: Guess that's one way to look at it.
We all do what we can.
Yeah, maybe you're right.
Some days it's just about getting through, nothing more.
Not sure if that's enough, though.
It's a relief, hearing that from someone for once.
Feels like everyone's pretending, but I can only keep up for so long.
I do wonder what 'still standing' even looks like now.
Appreciate you saying it.
Sometimes I doubt myself, seriously.
Feels like I'm always two steps behind what the city expects now.
If I lose my balance again, who's even going to notice?
But yeah, maybe being here still means something.
You get it, and that counts more than most things lately.
My whole life used to be about blending in, doing what was expected. Never questioned.
That doesn't work now. The system keeps tilting, always asking more.
It gets lonely pretending it's all under control when everyone's falling in some way.
Even the strong ones are faking.
You actually see it, and that's rare.
Maybe just talking about it, even for a minute, makes it less heavy.

factual.opener: You're holding back. What actually happened out there?
variants: People freaked after that big screen broadcast. Faces everywhere. Nobody knew what to do.
There were protests and more strange art popping up. Security was tighter for a while.
Everyone talks, but most stick to what's already in the feeds.
Council types just pointed fingers.
Lots of confusion, that's all.
First, those faces on every display set everyone on edge.
Some folks started digging, making their own signs, following rumors.
Council split. Some wanted lockdown, others just argued for show.
I kept to myself. Watched others get swept up in coin hunts and crowd meetings.
Didn't trust any guidance, from Council or the vanished crowd.
Nothing felt solid.
You saw what happened when those faces went live citywide. Nobody shrugged it off.
Street art everywhere, people hunting clues from shifting images, forums blowing up with speculation.
Council's infighting got messy: hardliners demanded more surveillance, some pitched 'dialogue' as if anyone wanted that.
Then the family rallies - thousands asking where the missing went. That changed the energy.
People like me... we watched how fast order turned into improvisation.
No surprise, I stuck with those who worked off the grid.
Hard not to th ink about which side I'd land on, if it came to that.
After that broadcast, everyone moved - overnight, the city felt different.
Families led rallies, faces painted into new protest art, data coins passed hand to hand, each sparking its own investigation.
Inside media, most of us quietly started following the vanished - not the Council's bulletins.
The Council lost control of the story and the street. Security officers pressured us, but some Innovators wanted to parley.
I watched old vanished staff come back, organizing aid with new codes, unreachable by official channels.
I've had to hide where my updates are coming from just to keep working.
My sympathies? Always more with the ones pulling real strings behind the curtain.
These games of power - that's the real headline now.
Everything splintered after Halden died, but the peer network was the real shift. Suddenly everyone had a way in - if you knew what to look for.
The coins and message trails gave old allies a reason to resurface. I know people who vanished months ago - now they're running safehouses, not hiding.
Families of the missing led mass marches. State media couldn't keep up. Stories about Council crackdowns got buried, so I started keeping my own footage.
Insiders and Innovators both tried to spin it, but truth is, the power's with whoever can move information fastest - and that's not the Council anymore.
Inside our building, I saw protocols fall apart. Trusted staff just bypassed security, hand-delivered evidence, used the peer network to swap leads.
People came to me asking what to publish. Me. Because half the Council news was rumor by then.
Personally, I never had patience for the whole algorithmic trust act. Grew up seeing how it erased stories. If anything, I'm rooting for the hidden networks now.
Council can pretend they'll regain order, but everyone sees through it.
Feels like a reckoning, not just a shift. For once, people are choosing what's real.

hobby.message: Origami help keep the noise out?
Find any ghosts in the tunnels?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Depends what you call rough.
I keep to the utility tunnels. Urban exploration's my thing.
Lot more kids poking around since that big broadcast.
Makes it crowded down there.
Yeah, a bit out of sorts today.
Spent hours in the old data tunnels - urban exploration's my hobby.
Since those broadcast faces, more folks down there painting walls.
Hard to find a quiet spot now.
Place used to be empty at night.
Seen stranger nights, honestly.
I do urban exploration - mostly tunnels and abandoned data centers.
Usually it's just me and some old wiring.
Last week, kids flooded the tunnels after that citywide broadcast.
Art everywhere - faces from the screens all over the concrete.
Hobby suddenly feels popular, which is saying something.
You're not wrong. Streets are restless, tunnels aren't much better.
Urban exploration's been my pastime for years. I go where others won't.
Spent last night in Gidro-6 tunnels - used to be quiet.
Ever since those vanished folks showed up on every screen, it's crowded below.
Was dodging protest art and masked kids for hours.
Still unwind though - bit of crawling, maybe a sip of home-brew.
City's mood's found its way underground.
Rough out there, sure. Feels like above and below switched places lately.
Urban exploration's been my escape - city's guts, old networks, quiet spots nobody cares for.
Lately, the hobby's changing. Since those vanished citizens hijacked the screens, tunnels are alive at night.
Was mapping a bypass under Sector 4 just last week - ran into three teens doing protest art.
They were replaying faces from the network, talking about clues in the city's decay.
Normally I'd duck out, but we shared the space, swapped stories - used to be solitude down there.
Feels like every crawl's part discovery, part group therapy now.
Guess the lines between hiding and belonging are thinner than I thought.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still poking around the old tunnels.
Not as quiet as it used to be lately.
Lot of fresh paint, odd tracks, nothing to see.
Guess everyone wants to leave their mark now.
Makes a simple job complicated.
Yeah, been down there with the bottle and my boots.
Used to be empty at night. Not anymore.
Saw some protest art cropping up like mold this week.
People act bold after those broadcasts, guess system's too busy to notice.
Makes it hard to tell who's there for fun and who's scouting for trouble.
I keep my circuits tight. That's all.
That's me. Still crawling pipes and sipping homebrew.
Whole scene's shifted since the faces hit those screens.
Tunnels are a magnet now - kids, activists, anybody trying to dodge the surface.
I can't patch a relay without tripping over someone painting a vanished face.
Last week, nearly stepped in fresh stencil ink near the old datacore vault.
Makes for good company sometimes, more risk others.
At least nobody expects you to talk politics underground.
Right as rain - urban exploring with spirits in my flask.
Since the Council's glitches, utility tunnels got lively. Protest art everywhere, peer net signals pulsing.
Saw three vanished-network kids mapping faces by hand, left a mural where I patch fiber.
It used to be just machines humming. Now it's arguing, art, sometimes out-loud grief.
Honestly, I don't mind sharing the space. Everyone's working things out in their own way.
Some of the data they leak helps me reroute old signals.
Nothing like a blackout to get the city rediscovering its hidden places.
Funny thing: I finally feel less like a ghost myself.
You know me. Pipes, homebrew, shadows. Never liked crowds, but that changed fast.
After those faces went public, every sealed corridor's alive - protest kids, search parties, lost cause types.
Last week, kids with vanished-coin tablets talked to me while painting the Council as ghosts.
They're piecing together disappearances using codes we used to patch illegally, back before the BCI indexed us all.
Suddenly, the city's secret places aren't so secret. Data leaks right out - sometimes through my hands.
Used to be I drank alone, fixed solo. Now I'm a mediator, translator, sometimes running crowd control underground.
I fixed a relay and left with five new rumors and one cryptic data coin.
The city used to ignore the tunnels. Now, they're the city's pulse.
Strange how it takes a collapse for people to look beneath their feet.

main.opener: Yeah... makes me wonder how your week's been.
variants: This week? Well, the city's had better ones.
Had a few repair jobs go quiet. People are keeping to themselves.
Heard some noise about those public screens acting up.
Guess I'm not exactly anyone's favorite at the moment.
Oh, you know, just your usual - stirred up a little trouble without meaning to.
Did a job, set off some alarms, and now the screens are all full of faces.
A few neighbors don't seem thrilled to see me these days.
Work's shrunk down to nothing. Funny how fast things turn.
Feels like someone swapped out the city overnight.
Suppose you caught the new faces on all the screens? That was my handiwork.
Hooked a hidden network up to the city's broadcast last week. Bypassed the usual handlers.
Now folks look at me like I'm contagious. My clients stopped calling.
Workshop's been empty, except for some nosy types poking around.
City's services are slowing down. People forming little committees. Like they forgot how to work together.
I thought I knew my place, but I'm starting to wonder.
It's been strange, Alex. I burned a few bridges when I triggered that citywide broadcast.
Used some old override codes, let the vanished folk talk to the whole city for once. Couldn't ignore what was festering beneath the system.
The faces you saw - Council and the missing all mixed together - that was me helping flip the city upside-down.
People here know now. They act different around me. Some are scared, some just angry I broke the silence.
Neighbors are organizing their own fixes, forming collectives. Feels like hope and confusion got poured into the water supply.
Lost clients, lost jobs. Even my so-called neutral ground isn't so neutral anymore.
Didn't think one risky choice could cut me off so fast, but here we are.
Let's just say I blew what little cover I had left, Alex. I'm the one who linked that shadow network to every public screen - faces, voices, the whole parade.
Wasn't about rebellion for the thrill of it, just got sick of patching over Council glitches while people vanished with no word.
I used to take pride in neutrality. Fix the leaks, keep everyone guessing and the system afloat. Now the city treats me like a virus.
First day after the broadcast, my workshop emptied fast. Colleagues gave me that look - like I'd put rot in their bread.
The system slowed, informal groups sprang up, but that old BCI grip is still twitching in the background, choking any real trust.
I was always a bit of an outsider, but now even the rebels hesitate to stand too close.
Feels odd - helped people find the missing, exposed Council rot, and still wound up more isolated than ever.
Honestly, I've never felt quite this alone before.
main.emotion: Honestly, I've never felt quite this alone before.

emotional.opener: Lenart, you're not the only one who's felt out on the edge here. You don't have to carry all that alone - you're seen, even if the system pretends otherwise.
variants: Suppose that's easy to say, harder to believe.
But I appreciate the effort.
Maybe you're right. Doesn't always feel like it, but maybe.
Not much comfort in being seen, though.
Thanks for not pretending it's all fine.
Yeah, it helps hearing that from someone not reading off a script.
Feels strange, having someone notice for once. Not sure what to do with it.
Most here just look through you.
Suppose a bit of being seen goes a long way.
That actually does mean something, hearing you say it straight.
Never thought I'd need reminding I'm not invisible, but tonight I did.
Funny how easy it is to get lost, even when you know every circuit in the walls.
I miss old times when you'd just nod and it'd be enough.
Feels like maybe there's still a bit of ground under me.
You know, I used to believe keeping to myself was safest. Didn't owe anyone anything, didn't risk much.
But the world's changed so much, it gets quiet in all the wrong places.
Honestly, I keep thinking anyone who sees me now just does it for the system, not for what's left of Lenart.
So, yes, it helps. Maybe more than I expected.
If someone like you can notice what slips through, maybe I'm not as lost as I thought.
Been awhile since I felt like someone spotted the real me - not just a line on a console.

factual.opener: You keep dancing around it, Lenart. If you know what's really going on in this city, just say it.
variants: Most of what you saw is what everyone saw.
Big faces, lots of noise, folks out on the street for once.
Council's rattled, but they're still holding the lines.
Anything past that is just rumor.
It's no secret the system's glitched up.
Some high-scorers got shoved to grunt work, made people nervous.
Everyone's chasing those data coins, but it's mostly confusion.
Council's splitting hairs, nothing settled yet.
I just keep my head low. Too many eyes watching.
City's on edge after the broadcast, sure.
Random folks got reassigned, no one trusts the next shift list.
People started finding weird coins packed with data, stirring up the missing's families.
The Council's at each other's throats - security's watching, Innovators pushing talk, Harmonists are ghosts now.
Wasn't long before families hit the streets, demanding answers instead of algorithms.
Whole city feels snapped out of its trance, kind of raw.
Never seen folks so jumpy. Even I'm picking my routes more carefully.
You saw those coins? They're more than just tokens - messages from the vanished, tucked in digital layers.
Halden, the old system head, left a backdoor. Now his secret network is talking to the public outright.
The city's upside down. Old BCI scores don't mean much, but the grip is still there, pulsing under the surface.
Council's at war with itself - no leader, just factions scrapping.
Services half-run by citizen crews. Sometimes feels like freedom, mostly just messy.
What I did threw the match, but these cracks were waiting.
I never cared for their order, but breaking it... Only brought silence for me.
Even now, most folks can't decide who to trust, except themselves.
Funny thing - Halden built in that peer-to-peer channel for the vanished years ago. Never told anyone.
I used the right override and the whole old ghost network came spilling out, crossing wires with the official feeds.
Everything's split - people hunting clues in coins, chasing the vanished, making up their own fix rules.
Council's fractured, Directorate wants to drag us all back to the lockstep, the Innovators talk like they want change, but none risk the whole truth.
I'm stuck between them - maintenance man, rebel outsider, safe for no one now.
Saw services actually get better for a day or two with citizen-run fixes... then the system's claw came back, bland but steady.
The vanished? They've got more leverage now than any Council suit.
Never thought calling out the rot would freeze me out this bad, even from people I was supposed to free.
All I wanted was to loosen the chain, not tear down the world, but these days it's hard to tell the difference.
